Understate: The claim may understate the true intention of the underwater statues, as the artist clarified that they were not intended as a tribute to the slave trade.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or mention of the statues being specifically related to slaves thrown overboard.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by linking the statues to the slave trade without sufficient evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by the artist, stating that the statues were not intended to have any connection to the Middle Passage or the slave trade.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the statues were not intended as a tribute to the slave trade, as clarified by the artist.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the connection between the statues and the slave trade, as there is no evidence supporting this link.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not considering the historical context of the clothing worn by some of the figures in the statues, which includes jeans that were not worn during the majority of the slave trade period.
